number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 20, 2016
												Whether you like this game or not will be extremely subjective. Some people will love it, some will hate it. While the style, music and overall atmosphere of the game are amazing, and it has significantly more gameplay than would be expected from a walking sim, the game can get frustrating at times, and what is there may just not be what floats your boat.First off, the style is amazing. The world looks incredible and eerie, rarely straying from a monochrome colour palate, which gives the world a strong surreal, alien quality. Add to that a soundtrack that alternates between beautiful and tense and you have a game with an atmosphere few games hope to achieve. This atmosphere IS the game, it's the star attraction and if it's not you're thing you aren't going to like the game.Another important thing to note is that, while this isn't a horror game, it feels like one at times. It can make you feel very, very uncomfortable, and while you are rarely in danger, the game makes you feel as if you're being stalked by... something.The story is threadbare in the traditional sense of the word. You are a girl lost in a world that clearly isn't your own. You're running away from something. This is all that is obvious, although the world itself does a decent job of telling a story of its own.Finally, I feel that, unlike other Walking Sims like Gone Home or Mirror Moon EP, it is completely justified to call this a game. The gameplay is a combination of first person platforming, that rarely becomes irritating, and a few atandars puzzles. However, despite the added gameplay over other similar titles, I can't stress enough that it is the atmosphere that makes NaissanceE. The eerie feeling of being alone in a world that may or may not be hostile is incredible. The best example I can think of is, if you have played and enjoyed a game like Riven, and it was the atmosphere that really got to you, you will probably enjoy NaissanceE. If not, look elsewhere.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 2, 2015
												Having a hard time rating this game, but in the end I have a harder time recommending it than not. Also, I have a hard time figuring how its pricetag is considered justifiable at $15. Seems like games of its ilk go for about $9.99. Value proposition is real I'm sad to say and, TO ME, this game is maybe worth $5-$8 to take a gamble on.NaissanceE has a very interesting visual style - its landscape is striking and has enough unique pieces to keep locations feeling fresh. I also have to give the nod to sound design, where it largely feels amorphous and evokes a sense of unease & foreboding. Sounds feel like they belong and have a purpose, without sounding like a recognizable variation of things more based in our world (i.e. boring reality :-p). The visual and aural experience is a pretty a cool and well rounded one. However, there are issues with the lighting sometimes proving to be too finicky. This basically happens during the more difficult platforming bits - almost always a bad idea in a 3D game - where you only have a couple of chances to succeed. After a handful of failures they dumb it down and pull out the equivalent to bowling-lane bumpers by decreasing gap sizes and such so that you can continue. I like that they have a way for you to move on, but this seems an inelegant way to do so. I have no problems if things like this occur when it feels like a failing of me or my abilities, but this feels like they recognize certain sections didn't work well and this was their concession - their patchwork solution. Other times you'll just be stuck trying to get past a section. I prefer this over the lessening of difficulty, though certain sections are just overly difficult when you are worrying about finicky 3D platforming while wrestling with darkness. Perhaps a better crutch would be for light to slowly increase as players continue to fail, giving them a chance to use pure skill to continue. Seems like there are more than a few platforms (or whole areas even) somewhat unfairly hidden in shadow. Or times when a light source decides it's going to run away after you've activated it, which might as well be a fail state rather than letting you bump along in perpetual darkness. Perhaps it is just me, perhaps I do just suck, but this is just how it seems in my (admittedly) short time with the game. The senses are certainly entertained with the games visual and aural flair, but the patience is tested a bit too much and feels like successes are further out of your control than they are within. I'll have a hard time coming back to this game.

												This game isn't for everyone. If you're the kind of person who enjoys being psychologically tested and don't mind being disoriented then you may enjoy the short trip this game provides. It never holds your hand. It just drops you in media res and leaves the rest up to you to figure out. content:
Posted: January 5, 2016
												Long version: Some parts took me a couple of tries to figure out, but eventually even I completed the game. I don't consider myself an amazing gamer or anything like that, but i felt this game was challenging enough for the average gamer to complete.I don't think the game was ment to be a purely exploration based game (probably why the game is getting any negativity at all since it was labled as one). Otherwise why would they even include death as a response to going the wrong way or making a huge mistake? The trial and error, the easter eggs and hidden dead ends... The fact that the only way to get a story, or rather an idea as to what is going on, is through extrapulating what the environment shows you, makes the game that much more compelling. yes you could add things to make it easier, but that doesn't always make a game better. The satisfaction of completion well outweighed the learning curve the game presented.Short version: I don't believe this game is for everyone, but i do believe anyone who can understand it's basic mechanics can complete it. Kind of like an easier platformer version of the dark souls series, the challenge and reward of figuring it all out yourself is just apart of it.

content:
Posted: July 9, 2016
												A walking/exploring game with absolutely zero plot or story, just you navigating your way through a massively huge area trying to figure out where to go next.The game world is rather impressive if drab in color. I don't think there's a single texture used anywhere in the game which probably allowed the developer to create massive areas and have it be viewable to the player without causing a video card meltdown.The game is mostly exploring with a few light based puzzles scattered throughout. The light/dark dynamic is interesting but definitely do not play the game if you're prone to issues due to flashing lights.It's designed to be played via keyboard and mouse but does support the xbox 360 PC controller though it's a bit clunky in it's implementation (walked off a ledge more than once after I tried to stop moving) and the game interface is clunky too.If you like this sort of game, it's a good buy, but maybe when it's on sale.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 7, 2016
												I've played many of these abstract exploration games, but this one was by far my favorite. The way the game manages to present game mechanics and a narrative, all purely using visual cues, is quite impressive. The game also never got frustrating or overly confusing. Maybe I just got lucky, but the longest I ever got stuck for was a couple minutes, which is impressive for a game like this that does absolutely no hand holding. I felt like I was getting lost at times, but the game is well designed and your intuition is almost always right.The main thing you notice at first is the gorgeous and mind bending level design. It managed to impress over and over as the game progresses, by bringing new elements and always evolving.What truly brought this game to the next level though was the soundtrack and audio work. For an indie game, this had an almost blockbuster movie level sound design. It accompanied and augmented the mood of the level, bringing a whole new depth to it.As for the gameplay, each chapter managed to completely spin things around and keep things interesting. Sure, there wasn't much story, but this is definitely a beautiful piece worth experiencing.

												I think this game succeeded in what it was trying to do. I absolutely loved the level design, the atmosphere, the music, the gameplay, the environments... This entire game creates a wonderfully unique mood, even among and above games that have a simlar look or feel. 												NaissanceE sparkles your curiosity at every corner of this dark, mysterious world. It's moody, unique, weird, intriguing, the soundtrack is awesome, fits very well with the atmosphere. The game never lets you down, there is no clichés here, every new place you go, you are always surprised, there is always a new kind of cool experience to be had, the game rewards your exploration in many ways. The is no backstory really, this is focused on gameplay, exploration, mystery, mood. If you ever read any work of Tsutomu Nihei like BLAME! or BIOMEGA, this is a MUST play. NaissanceE is an astonishing experience that I will never forget.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 17, 2016
												I played this a while ago, but just remembered the experience and want to review. I personally love this 'game', but I honestly put it into my cart on BundleStars just to qualify for a discount since it was the only first person game left to choose from at the time.However, I've played it, and it's been a great experience.NaissanceE is another of these artistic exploration type games, with a focus on environment design over raw features. However..! NaissanceE has sprinting, fall damage and slight character momentum which make you feel less like a rolling camera and more like a human being. That is a fantastic choice, because after a while of immersive play you get the feeling of being an explorer in the landscape.The area types vary through the game, with both low points and high points. Some of the weaker areas were just little platformer rooms, but at least they had puzzles instead of relying on pure jump timing.For me, the game had a clear high point: You come across this city like area, a spacious indoor location with spires and skycrapers. Little rooms resembling bars or apartment stairwells bring your mind into modern Earth to hint that the area is residential.It's probably just done for art, but after a while exploring that section of the game the effect was great, you begin to feel like you're intruding on ruins of someone before you. It felt beautiful but extremely unnerving, a few games have a lost civilisation theme (Elder Scrolls Dwarves, Mass Effect Protheans, Halo Forerunners) so you know how it felt to be there.NaissanceE does have a few downsides however.The price might not be perfect, since even as someone who takes my time I doubt there's enough game time for the cost.There is a UI noise I remember as having extreme bass on it, so loud it made audio clipping in my headphones. Weird.Also the checkpointing is unusual... In some places there are checkpoints every few feet, but in a later area I got caught under some machinery, died and went back literally to the start of the chapter.All in all I enjoyed it. I'd recommend the experience, but just be warned that your experience will vary on your tastes.. If you like art games, surrealism, ghostly environments or first person exploration you'll love this.If you're itching for a shooter or purely puzzle-based game then give it some thought before purchase.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 2
Product received for free
												This is a beautiful platformer study of space and lighting that would hopefully one day be built upon to become a foundation for a more fully-realized game.NaissanceE juggles a number of curious gameplay mechanics (breathing to run; the treacherousness of light creating challenges in otherwise straightforward locations). What it seems to lack, however, is a sense of purpose. It feels a bit too game-y and poor on detail for an immersive artistic game that would invite us to simply soak up its atmophere—and a bit too loose, directionless and not challenging enough to be gameplay-based. That is not to say that it's bad; but neither is it good. More than anything, it's just lacking in production quality, presentation, and that elusive component that would make it breathtaking rather than just interesting.Like I said before, here's to hoping that discoveries made in NaissanceE will be put to better use someplace else.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 7
												It's hard to say whether I'd recommend this or not. If you're looking for an epic game with story and action and so on, then this isn't for you; but if you're looking to just live an experience that's quite unique then yeah, try it out.The game never gives you any clear indication as to what's happening, why it's happening and what you're supposed to do. You rely purely on your instinct and just get through the game. Most of the challenges are overcomable with some practice, but there are a couple of instances, one in particular, that you will NOT solve without a sneak peak on the internet. Well, you might, but (hint hint) I was playing with really low volume so I had no indication at all that anything I was doing was of any use; it takes no advantage of any mechanic the game has tought you, nor is it something that 'exhausting all possibilities' will lead you to success. But other than that, the game can be tought but fair.There are plenty of sites in this game that are truly unique, you'd have never seen things like them before, nor would you see them in any other game. And the way that the visuals try to tie in with the music is also quite lovely at times.This game is for the curious, and it's nothing I can sell any more without spoiling anything.

												Amazing game! You will experience every feeling human can have playing this game. Happiness, sadness, feeling weird, confused, lost, like wft is this, omg this have no sense at all... Best to describe maybe to compare a movie or tv series, "lost" meets "the cube", some areas are simply breathtaking, long walks, or runs, others need intense focus to pass, some are brainteasers, puzzles, alot of them dont make sense. Tell me if you ever seen a way to find exit out of a locked room is following: do nothing, remove hands from your keyboard and mouse and just wait. Door will only then open. Last thing you would think of to do. Well this game does that. Totaly messes with your mind. Its a platformer, puzzle, exploration game, with almost no knowlege of that is happening. For me it was like im in a movie. Takes alot of patience to complete. Dont give up.

												Played this years ago and it's still the most interesting game I've ever played. Best played in one go and at night as the longer you play the more you get sucked into its dark and abstract universe.I'm just really sad it's not as known as it should be. More people need to at least try it, it's too beutiful to be ingnored by so many. As an ignorant interloper with no idea what's going on, you feel so spectacularly inferior the whole way through, an aspect I've never felt so strongly before in any other game, which still holds true to this day. And that's coming form someone with more than 300 games in their library alone. And not a single texture was used to achieve this, being minimalistic, which is beyond impressive in my opinion.You shouldn't jump into the game expecting to have fun. It's way more of an experience than it is a game in that sense.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 15
												At its heart, NaissanceE is intended not for those who want to experience a "game", but rather the ambient darkness a la Tsutomo Nihei's BLAME!, perhaps coupled with Piranesi's "Carceri". The experience you have is manifold, and compares well to Kairo (another game in a similar vein available on Steam). Where NaissanceE is pseudo-linear exploration and the accidental occlusion of puzzles - they sort of show up, rather than being presented to you as in Kairo - the atmosphere is much more pronounced here. NaissanceE reveals a measure of spectral light, causing movement to be rare and the interplay of light and shadow quite spectacular. If you can deal with and enjoy a game that can be quite difficult in its platforming aspects (moreso than Kairo) but rewards you with the visual splendor that Pauline Oliveros' "Deep Listening" album evoked aurally - monolithic devices and structures rising from the gloom of nothingness, with a rather haunting ambient feel - definitely pick this up.This is Danielewski's "House of Leaves" in visual form. Where does form define itself if not within the darkness of our own eyes?
